text: - Hi everyone, I'm Brian O'Flaherty Wills.

I'm the worldwide go-to-market
lead for AWS IoT TwinMaker.
I'm really pleased to speak to you today
about a collaboration with AWS

and Siemens Digital
Industries on Digital Twin.

And today I'm gonna talk to
you about this collaboration,

show you an example of
how this collaboration
is resulting for innovation for customers.

So first, a few words
about this collaboration.
Siemens Digital Industries is a company
that needs no introduction

for anyone working in
the industrial setting,

but this collaboration is
something relatively new
that we announced last year.
Siemens, of course, provide software
to create comprehensive Digital Twins

across the value chain,
including the design,
manufacturing and service parts

of the product and
manufacturing life cycle.
And through collaboration with AWS,

we're actually bringing
Siemens' Digital Twin technology

into the cloud, leveraging
the deep industry expertise

of Siemens with the scale
and global reach of AWS,
combining different services
and bringing those to customers.
Our recent new service, AWS IoT TwinMaker,
which we launched at re:Invent last year

is at the cornerstone
of this collaboration.

What customer challenges are
we actually looking to solve?

Well, Siemens and AWS
are working on behalf
of our joint customers to bring together
the different pieces of our technology.

When we're looking at customers
in the manufacturing sector,
we're looking at a lot
of common challenges across this space.
Our customers are talking to us a lot

about improving efficiency,
improving uptime
and OEE and operational metrics,
as well as really driving insights
for stakeholders in engineering,
stakeholders in the plant floor,
and basically bringing the data

that's coming into the AWS
and out of their operation,
bringing that into a place

where stakeholders can actually
use it and take actions
and make decisions against it.

So you're seeing a couple
of example use cases here.

Increasing product complexity
across the life cycle,
optimizing material costs

and getting the most
out of material inputs
without giving up quality,

increasing productivity,
increasing flexibility,
reducing downtime and cycle time.

And of course, everyone
needs to be thinking
about addressing sustainability

and getting the most out
of their energy inputs.

So these are some of
the customer challenges

that, again Siemens
and AWS joint customers
are talking to us about.

And where does Digital
Twin fit into all this?
Well, Digital Twin is really an example

of bringing all of these
different data sources
through manufacturing and operations,

and bringing those to light
for customers, for end users,
in the shop floor, in the control room,

in the operation room,
in the management room.

Our example here is of a
cold brew coffee plant.
So we're actually gonna show you today
an example of a Digital Twin,
a comprehensive Digital Twin,
put together jointly by Siemens and AWS

that demonstrates the full
value of the Siemens portfolio,

in combination with
the AWS Cloud Services.
So we're gonna walk through

this cold brew coffee
plant Digital Twin demo.

What's really interesting
about this demo is

that it really takes a full
picture of the life cycle

of the equipment in the plant,
going from a plant-level view

to the very specifics of an
individual piece of equipment.

So I'm going to not spend
too much time on this slide.
I want to get to this actual demo
and walk you through it.
Before we get there, though,
let's talk a little bit about the how,
and we talked about that view
of going from the plant level

all the way to the individual
piece of equipment.

So really what our customers
are trying to do is

take data sources from
across industrial operations,

bring those data sources
together in a model
of their plant and their operation,

and then serve that
together with a 3D view
to bring that data in context
and serve it up to end users at scale.
So you've really got the data sources.
You've got the model,
and you've got that front end view
to serve up to users at scale.

So if you look at the
demo architecture here,

we're really speaking
to those three pieces

with different elements of
the Siemens and AWS portfolio.
So if I start on the right-hand side,
what we're gonna be showing you is
a front end developed on Siemens Mendix.
Mendix is the leading low code platform
for industrial solutions.

So Mendix is a fantastic
solution for taking data sources
and helping customers, real users,

to visualize those data
sources and bring them together
and take actual insights against them.
In terms of the Digital Twin model itself,

this is really being driven
off AWS IoT TwinMaker,
and AWS I TwinMaker, as I said,

is a service that we
launched at re:Invent in 2021

that helps customers build
and manage Digital Twins.

What we're gonna see
from AWS IoT TwinMaker

is the bringing together of
those different data sources

into a common model that
represents the entire plant.
And then what are those data sources?

So those data sources are
going to be live data sources.

Those are data sources
coming from SCADA equipment,
coming from cameras,
coming from condition monitoring sensors.

Those data sources are gonna
be transactional data sources
that govern the operations of the plant,

so things like the
manufacturing execution system,
the MRP system.
A lot of these, by the way,
coming from Siemens technologies,
like Siemens Teamcenter, Siemens Opcenter,
and then the other data source
that we're gonna be looking at is

simulated data sources or
synthetic data sources.
Here Siemens has an amazing portfolio
in terms of being able to predict

and plot sensor values that
we can't actually measure,
so using simulation technologies
we're going to show that as well.
So we have transactional data sources.
We have live data sources.
We have simulated data sources,
all coming together in this Digital Twin.
So let's take a look.
So we're in the cold brew coffee plant.

Before we get there, this
is an asset-level view,

so looking at the entire
scope of operations,
including this one particular plant,

but you can see, this is
really an at-a-glance view

of the entire operation

So in this case, we wanna take
a look at a specific issue
or a specific anomaly within the plant.

And here, what we're gonna do
is dive into this visual view

of the entire plant floor
layout that's augmented
with these UI widgets

that represent individual

and the data sources
associated with those assets.
So in this case, what we're doing is

zooming right into this
part of the conveyor.
We're looking at this robotic arm
where we've detected an anomaly,

we've detected a strain
threshold exceeded.

So you'll see on the
right-hand side at the top,
we've got some measured values.
We've also got a simulated value,

and that's gonna be one
of those unmeasured values

that we're producing using
the Siemens xDT solution.
And also, of course, we have the view,
the live view of the camera there.
So all of those different data sources
plotted against each other.

So that's nice, now that
we know there's an anomaly,
but really our next question
is going to be well, what's going on?
What is really the issue at hand here?
And so we wanna be able to navigate

to where we can click
and double-click down
on those details of that robotic arm,
and here's where you're seeing that.
And here's the real power
of linking this operational Digital Twin
into operational insights from MindSphere,

or in this case, right
into the PLM system itself.
So we're gonna be looking
at a bunch of time series data here

that we're gonna be able
to plot and window against,
relative to that robotic arm.

And here we go, we're
gonna open an up Teamcenter

where we're actually
gonna see the PLM system

of that robotic arm,
and be able to go down

to really detailed levels,
in terms of the 3D geometry,
in terms of the component parts,

in terms of understanding
where is this robotic arm used?
Why are we seeing this anomaly?

Where else are we seeing
these kinds of anomalies,

these kinds of issues,

So some real power going from
the end-to-end view here.
The next step is,
so I've seen these anomalies here.
I've seen some ideas
on how I wanna take a corrective action.

What I wanna do is simulate
the output of that.

And so here, I've just gone
into the Mendix view again,

and run a simulation
against those new values.
So again, incredible power here,

going from the asset level
view, the plant level view,

and looking at a specific
issue within the plant,

going right into the
the details of the data

all of this housed in Siemens
MindSphere IoT platform,

into the actual lifecycle
management software,

and into the simulation software

all through a single user experience.

So really powerful
capabilities being shown here.
So that's actually not all.
In addition to the cold brew coffee demo,
and those capabilities we talked about,

I want to highlight some
additional Digital Twin use cases

that Siemens and AWS can
bring to life for customers.
When we think about Digital Twin
in the design part of the life cycle,
so when you're designing, laying out,
simulating a plant operation,
Siemens has some amazing technology
that we can bring to customers.

So in this case, we're
looking at a simulation

and optimization of an
entire plant layout.
We're looking at validating,

and looking at the fluid
flow through that equipment.

We're looking at optimizing
packaging processes
and simulating robot-human interactions.

All of these capabilities
are gonna come in

in the front end of the
design cycle for operations.
So again, we're looking at everything
from design, commissioning,
building, operating, and maintaining
an end-to-end plant, in this case.
So some really exciting technologies
and some really exciting solutions
that we can bring to life for customers.
So to sum up, Siemens Xcelerator portfolio

and AWS services, including
AWS IoT TwinMaker,

we're innovating on
behalf of our customers
to bring these technologies to life
and to drive these technologies at scale.
Developers can create Digital Twins

from the very simplest use
cases for a single machine
to the most complex end-to-end solutions

for full plants combining
these technologies.

And we're really excited
to bring this to you,
and to share more with you.
If you have questions or ideas
